channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: He Was Ready to Retire. But the Coronavirus Took Him.
item.description: A journey down several blocks of one Pennsylvania city tells the story of the virus in America — of illness, financial strain and rising tension.
item.dc:creator: Michael Powell
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: North Wyoming Street in Hazleton, Pa., on April 18. Five days along a few blocks of old, worn rowhouses and storefronts here revealed the virus to be all around.

item.title: Ahmaud Arbery’s Killing Will Go to Grand Jury as Graphic Video Emerges
item.description: Mr. Arbery, 25, was killed after two men pursued him in a South Georgia neighborhood, a confrontation that was caught on video. A prosecutor said charges should be considered in the case.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset

item.title: With New Hot Spots Emerging, No Sign of a Respite
item.description: While cities like New York have seen a hopeful drop in cases, upticks in other major cities and smaller communities have offset those decreases.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman, Mitch Smith and Amy Harmon
item.media:description: A neighborhood in New York City, which has seen a drop in new cases of the coronavirus.

item.title: Money for Welfare Instead Funded Concerts, Lobbyists and Football Games, Audit Finds
item.description: According to a state audit, Mississippi allowed tens of millions of dollars in federal anti-poverty funds to be used in ways that did little or nothing to help the poor.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset
item.category: Davis, John (Mississippi Department of Human Services)
item.media:description: Shad White, the Mississippi state auditor, right, and Hinds County District Attorney Jody Owens discuss the auditor’s office investigation about millions in federal money meant for the poor, in February in Jackson, Miss.

item.title: 3 People Killed in Shooting at California High School Parking Lot
item.description: The three teenagers were killed in a shooting at Golden West High School in Visalia, Calif. The police said they were not students there.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Sheyanne N Romero/The Times-Delta, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A damaged fence outside Golden West High School in Visalia, Calif. Three teenagers, none of whom were students at the school, were killed in a shooting in the parking lot there on Tuesday night.

item.title: Democrats Press Judicial Nominee, a McConnell Protégé, on Health Care Views
item.description: Judge Justin Walker seems headed for confirmation to an important appeals court despite concerns by critics that he would help unravel the Affordable Care Act.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky and the majority leader, has known Judge Walker since the judge was in high school.

item.title: Coronavirus Makes Cooling Centers Risky, Just as Scorching Weather Hits
item.description: Officials are scrambling to find ways to protect residents against dueling threats of extreme heat and the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:description: American cities traditionally rely on cooling centers to protect the most vulnerable. Above, a center for older people near Times Square in 2006.

item.title: Israeli High Court Lets Netanyahu Form Government, Despite Indictments
item.description: The court rejected petitions seeking to disqualify Netanyahu from leading a new government because he faces trial on felony corruption charges.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel during an event in Kiryat Arba, an Israeli settlement in the West Bank, in February.

item.title: To Fight Virus in Prisons, C.D.C. Suggests More Screenings
item.description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention confirmed that detention facilities are hot spots for infection and recommended regular symptom screenings.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: An inmate cleaning a jail cell at Las Colinas Women’s Detention Facility in Santee, Calif., last month.

item.title: Auto Plant Shutdown Spares an Essential: Corvette Parts
item.description: Big U.S. automakers have kept the lights on at a few factories, including a General Motors plant in Indiana making the Corvette chassis.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:credit: Kaiti Sullivan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The General Motors plant in Bedford, Ind., makes chassis for the Chevrolet Corvette.

item.title: The Compost by My Couch: How (and Why) I Started an Odorless Bin at Home
item.description: New York City has suspended its composting program because of the coronavirus. Here’s an alternative that’s easy, clean and good for the climate.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: An organic waste bin in New York. The city has stopped collecting compost because of budget cuts related to the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Did a Mutation Turbocharge the Coronavirus? Not Likely, Scientists Say
item.description: A preliminary report posted online claimed that a mutation had made the virus more transmissible. Geneticists say the evidence isn’t there.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, via Reuters
item.media:description: A colored scanning electron micrograph of a dying cell infected with the coronavirus, with viral particles in red.

item.title: Supreme Court Divided Over Obamacare’s Contraceptive Mandate
item.description: The justices considered whether the Trump administration may allow employers to refuse to provide free insurance coverage for birth control on religious or moral grounds.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:description: About 70,000 to 126,000 women could lose contraceptive coverage from their employers if the Trump administration prevails.

item.title: Unemployment Numbers Will Be Terrible. Here's What You Need to Know.
item.description: Government figures due Friday will undoubtedly show that job losses in April were the worst ever. But they could provide key hints about the recovery.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:description: A deserted shopping mall on Long Island. The April employment report is expected to reflect big job losses among retail workers.

item.title: Coronavirus Masks and Testing Kits: Firm Set Up by G.O.P. Operatives Under Scrutiny
item.description: Blue Flame Medical boasted that it could acquire masks, testing kits and other equipment to respond to the pandemic. State and local governments paid up — and are still waiting for delivery.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel
item.media:description: Emergency medical technicians donning personal protective equipment before responding to a call in the Bronx last month. Local governments across the country turned to firms like Blue Flame Medical to help them get the equipment they needed.

item.title: Avraham Rabby, Blind Diplomat and Advocate, Is Dead at 77
item.description: He waged a successful campaign to overturn a State Department rule prohibiting the blind from becoming Foreign Service officers.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:credit: Andrew Councill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Avraham Rabby in 2007, as he prepared to retire from the Foreign Service. He was the first blind person hired as a diplomat by the State Department.

item.title: Jana Prince, a Selfless Social Worker, Dies at 43
item.description: She had cerebral palsy, but her interest was in helping others with their problems. She died of the novel coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:description: Jana Prince was teased as a child because of her cerebral palsy. “She never let that stop her from reaching her goals,” her brother said. “She dedicated her life to social services.”

item.title: Biden Leads Trump in First Poll to Address Sexual Assault Allegation
item.description: In the first national survey asking voters about the allegations, Joe Biden widened his lead over President Trump in a head-to-head matchup that has continued to grow in the last couple of months.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello and Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. during a campaign event in Sumter, S.C., in February.

item.title: Betsy DeVos Completes Sexual Assault Rules
item.description: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos released final regulations for schools dealing with sexual misconduct, giving them the force of law for the first time and bolstering due-process rights.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.media:description: The rules preserve Education Secretary Betsy DeVos’s broad goals in overhauling Title IX.

item.title: Obama Says G.O.P.’s Biden Inquiry Promotes ‘Russian Disinformation’
item.description: The letter came in response to a November request from two Republican senators seeking Obama administration meeting records related to Ukrainian officials.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:description: Former President Barack Obama in January 2017.

item.title: Coronavirus in California: What Is the Effect on Agriculture?
item.description: Wednesday: A conversation with the peach farmer David Mas Masumoto on the ways the pandemic is changing the food supply chain.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: David Mas Masumoto inspecting the peaches in his orchard in Del Rey, Calif., in 2013.

item.title: On Politics: Dissolving the Coronavirus Task Force
item.description: Questions about the role of science in the federal response: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Coronavirus, White House Task Force, U.S. Senate: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: Live Coronavirus News and Updates
item.description: The group, backed by Amazon, opposes President Trump’s demands that the Postal Service ratchet up its package delivery rates. Nearly one in five children in the U.S. are not getting enough to eat.

item.title: Trump Pushes Young Republicans Away. Abortion Pulls Them Back.
item.description: On everything from climate change to marijuana, the generational divide that is evident among Democrats is no less present on the other side of the aisle. It’s just less visible.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:description: Abortion opponents gathered outside the Supreme Court in Washington in January.

item.title: How My Boss Monitors Me While I Work From Home
item.description: As we shelter in place in the pandemic, more employers are using software to track our work — and us.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano

item.title: What It’s Like to Have Coronavirus
item.description: There’s a list of coronavirus symptoms that many can now recite from memory. And then there’s how it actually feels when you have it.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times and Thoka Maer

item.title: Loeffler Got Lucrative Parting Gift From Public Company en Route to the Senate
item.description: The parent company of the New York Stock Exchange, which her husband runs, changed compensation terms to give Kelly Loeffler, a top executive, awards worth millions of dollars as she left for Congress.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos and David Enrich
item.media:description: Senator Kelly Loeffler, Republican of Georgia, is the Senate’s newest and wealthiest member.

item.title: Live Stock Market Tracker During the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: Businesses in the retail and service sector have been hit hard by stay-at-home orders.

item.title: Coronavirus Global Tracker: Britain, Germany, India
item.description: Among the virus victims: the European Union, which predicts its economy will shrink 7.4 percent this year, and Putin’s approval ratings, which have plummeted as Russia’s economic woes deepen.
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Berlin’s Museum Island on Wednesday. The country will enter its second major phase of lifting its lockdown in the coming days.

item.title: How Kushner’s Volunteer Force Led a Fumbling Hunt for Medical Supplies
item.description: Young, inexperienced workers scrambled to sort through tips on equipment desperately needed to fight the coronavirus while warehouses ran bare and doctors made their own gear.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Confessore, Andrew Jacobs, Jodi Kantor, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Luis Ferré-Sadurní

item.title: Dallas Salon Owner Is Jailed for Defying Order to Stay Closed
item.description: Shelley Luther tore up a cease-and-desist letter after she reopened Salon À La Mode on April 24.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: Shelley Luther received a citation on April 24 for reopening her Dallas salon during the lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Some children are developing a mysterious illness that appears to be linked to the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons

item.title: Setback for Quincy Jones on Payment for Michael Jackson Film
item.description: A California appellate court rejected most of the $9.4 million Mr. Jones was awarded by a jury in 2017 after he claimed he had been shortchanged on record sale royalties.
item.dc:creator: Colin Moynihan
item.media:description: Quincy Jones produced much of Michael Jackson’s music, including the hit albums “Off the Wall” and “Thriller.”

item.title: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg Hospitalized for Gallbladder Treatment
item.description: The Supreme Court said she expected to participate in Wednesday’s oral arguments by telephone from the hospital.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg in October in Washington.

item.title: New York Must Hold Democratic Presidential Primary, Judge Rules
item.description: The primary in June, which had been canceled over concerns about the coronavirus, should still be held, with all qualifying candidates restored to the ballot, a federal judge ruled.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Elizabeth D. Herman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voting in the Bronx during the 2018 midterm elections. This year’s Democratic presidential primary in New York was canceled late last month.

item.title: Administration to Phase Out Coronavirus Task Force
item.description: The group had provided President Trump a backdrop for his daily briefings while working to coordinate the government response to the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland, Maggie Haberman and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Dr. Anthony Fauci and Dr. Deborah Birx before a coronavirus task force briefing at the White House in March.

item.title: Zoom (Money) Bombing
item.description: Confined to their basements and mansions, politicians and donors take the dollar dance online.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti

item.title: Trump Gives Phoenix Mask Factory Visit a Campaign Feel
item.description: One of the president’s last “Keep America Great” campaign rallies before the virus largely halted his travel was on Feb. 19 in Arizona.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: President Trump touring a Honeywell mask factory in Phoenix on Tuesday.

item.title: Who is Rick Bright? The Coronavirus Whistle-Blower Who Said The Trump Administration Steered Contracts to Cronies
item.description: Rick Bright, the ousted chief of the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Agency, said he was pressured to steer millions of dollars to the clients of a well-connected consultant.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority

item.title: Trump’s Inspector General Pick Vows Independence From the White House
item.description: Brian D. Miller, the White House lawyer tapped to oversee the Treasury Department’s $500 billion bailout, said he would not be influenced by political pressure.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Brian D. Miller, a White House lawyer who is President Trump’s nominee to serve as a special inspector general, faced questions about whether he would be independent of the White House.

item.title: Senators Descend on Quiet Capitol, Sacrificing Pomp for Safety’s Sake
item.description: With the Senate back in session, masked lawmakers, hushed corridors and socially distanced news conferences and hearings gave an eerie feel to the Capitol Hill routine.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.category: Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, during a news conference on Tuesday at the Senate Hart Office Building. Many aides and senators wore masks.

item.title: Pair Is Arrested on First Fraud Charges Tied to Small-Business Loan Program
item.description: The case against two men from New England is part of the Justice Department’s effort to fight crimes related to the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shuttered businesses in Jackson Heights, Queens, last month. The loans were intended to help small businesses during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Ji Chaozhu, Interpreter for China During Nixon’s Trip, Dies at 90
item.description: With his flawless English, he sometimes translated for both American and Chinese officials, making him the “indispensable man.”
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.media:description: Ji Chaozhu, center right, stood by Zhou Enlai’s side as he greeted President Nixon during the historic 1972 visit to China.
